text: It has been proposed that frameshifting is a common mechanism to increase protein-coding capacity of small genomes such as those of viruses and mitochondria. In agreement with this proposal, frameshifting is common in mitochondrial genes, and genome size seems to correlate with the abundance of frameshifting (Seligmann, 2010) . In fact, some organisms display a high complexity in frameshifting: In the dinoflagellate Perkinsus marinus, the mitochondrial gene that encodes cytochrome c oxidase subunit 1 can shift up to 10 times within the same mRNA sequence in order to produce the correct gene product (Masuda et al., 2010) . Clearly, such complex frameshifting requires efficient regulatory control.
